child:
Two friends captured by Moors have money to ransom only
one.

The ransomed one returns home, gets
money and buys the other‘s freedom. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Man who has counseled friend in assassination asks to be
killed on the other’s body.
Friend‘s intercession saves man from execution.

Man is abducted by pirates and kept in slavery forty years. Upon his return his
friend divides his earnings with him. Italian Novella: *Rotunda.

Hands of friends extend through sides of tombs and clasp in
death.
Successful rival gives his lady to unsuccessful friend.

Friends bind themselves each to grant every desire of the
other. Irish myth: Cross.
Danger of one saint voluntarily incurred by another.

content: Man refuses to follow friend in wicked conduct.

Scala Celi 11a No. 66; Alphabet No. 56; Italian Novella:
Rotunda.
Sitting in a circle of feasts.

Friends bound in brotherhood through partaking of milk from the
same woman. *Cosquin Études 247ff.; Wiedemann Am Urquell III 259ff.
child: Friendship starts at babyhood: two babies exchanged.

content:
Friends take oath of brotherhood by means of mixing their blood. *Type 1364;
**Encyc. Rel. Ethics II 717a, 857ff.; **H. C. Trumbull The Blood Covenant
(London, 1887); *Chauvin VII 20 No. 373D; *Hibbard 145 n. 3; Fb “blod” IV 46b;
Nitze MPh IX 291; DeVries Acta Philologica Scandinavica III 106; *Basset RTP VI
577--XXV 438 passim; *Julian Revue d’Ethnographie et de Trad. Pop. II 1ff.; **H. Tegnæus Blood-Brothers
(Stockholm, 1952). -- Irish myth: Cross: Icelandic: *Boberg; Tuamotu: Stimson
MS (z-G 13/203); Africa: Stanley 274.
child: Saint makes blood covenant with animals.

Drinking mixture of blood, milk, and wine as pledge of
covenant.
Sworn brethren and blood brethren avenge each other.

Surviving blood brother to watch three nights in
grave-mound.

Icelandic: Egils saga ok
Asm., Lagerholm 28 (cf. introd. xxiv--xxix).

content:
Friends take an oath of lasting brotherhood. *Type 516; Rösch FFC
LXXVII 98; *Hibbard 68 n. 7, 145 n. 3; Child IV 146f.; Wesselski Märchen 187
No. 2; *Krappe Bulletin Hispanique XXXIX 17; *Abeles “Die Burgschaft als Motif in der jüdischen Literatur” Monatsch. f. Geschichte u. Wissenschaft der Juden LX
213ff., 263ff. -- English: Wells 158 (Amis and Amiloun); Icelandic: Olrik
Sakses Oldhistorie I (1892) 59ff., *Boberg; Italian Novella: *Rotunda; Jewish:
*Neuman, bin Gorion Born Judas@2 IV 14, 20, 274; India: Thompson-Balys; Korean:
Zong in-Sob 63 No. 35.
child: Friends take oath of brotherhood by exchanging flowers. India: Thompson-Balys.

Human sons of animal companions go together on adventures
Africa.
Saints exchange bachalls as mark of affection.
Friendship between a prince and common man.
Friends want to divide good and evil.
Dying hero sends greetings to friends.
Friends want their children to be friends too.

Dying man asks friends to let his son inherit his
friendship together with his father’s weapons.
One friend dies shortly after the other.
Man wins wife for his friend.

Friends given the power of reading each other’s secret
thoughts.

content:
Refusal to receive preferred help until series of stories
has been told.
Friend sacrifices his life for the other.
child:
Man knowing of murder plot against his friend disguises and
is killed in his place.
(Cf. †P361.1.) Scala Celi 9b No. 61; Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content: Friends offer to die for each other.

(Bürgschaft.) Each
falsely confesses crime so as to save the other. Neither guilty. Often combined
with †P325. **Abeles “Die Bürgschaft als Motif
in der jüdischen Literatur” Monatschr. f. Geschichte
u. Wissenschaft der Juden LX 213ff., 263ff.; **K. Kelling Das Bürgschaftsmotiv
in der französischen Literatur (Leipzig diss., 1915); *Chauvin III 124 No. 113,
V 215f., VIII 194ff. IX 16f.; *Hdwb. d. Märchens I 350a s.v. “Bürgschaft”; Köhler-Bolte II 557,
580f.; Gaster Exempla Nos. 362, 419; Basset 1001 Contes II 293ff.; Boccaccio
Decameron X No. 8 (*Lee 330); Fischer Zs. f. deutsche Morgenländische Ges.
LXXII 290; Bolte Zs. f. Vksk. XXI 193 n. 4, 194; Scala Celi 10a, 11b Nos. 62,
68; bin Gorion Born Judas IV 20, 274; Alphabet Nos. 53, 57. -- Spanish Exempla:
Keller; Italian Novella: *Rotunda.
child: Competition in friendship: prisoner and jailor.

Officer in charge of prison offers to let his friend
escape, though his own life will be forfeited. The friend refuses; tells
officer to let king think he has escaped and if the king demands his life the
officer can produce the prisoner. King hears of the generosity and forgives the
prisoner. Chauvin V I No. 1.
Friend gives false witness to set free his accused friend.

content:
Porcupine asks rabbit for hospitality. When rabbit
complains of being pricked, porcupine tells him to leave if he does not like
it. Italian Novella: Rotunda.

Murderer of a man’s father takes refuge in his house and is saved by him.
*Chauvin II 198 No. 31.
child:
Nobleman forces escaping prisoner to accept his
hospitality.

Intercedes for his pardon.
Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Guest in disguise or under false name.

Refugee entertained in holy place (church, monastery,
etc.).

content: Hosts refrain from telling guest of death in household.

Wesselski Archiv
Orientální II 431; Greek: Euripides Alcestis.
Eating a man‘s salt creates mutual obligation. *Chauvin VI 196 No. 368.

Host
places imaginary feast before guest, who accepts it in the same spirit. Guest‘s
courtesy is rewarded by real feast. *Chauvin V 163 No. 86; Arabian: Burton
Nights I 317.
Student enters competition with his master.
child:
Is overcome by the latter‘s tricks. Italian Novella:
*Rotunda.

content: Shabby hospitality forces guests to leave.

Master demands that servant tell him of his faults as well
as of his good qualities.

If host does not return, the house shall belong to the
guest.

So declares the host as he departs
on a mission for the guest. *Chauvin V 209 No. 120 n. 1; Japanese: Ikeda.

Strangers entertained by family to whose hitching-ring they
happen to tie their horses.

Thus confusion
avoided as to where strangers are to be entertained. Italian: L. de Francia
Novellino (Torino, 1930), Rotunda.

child: Faithless men-servants corrupt the maids in the household.
Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 209; Italian Novella: Rotunda.
Servant planning to possess his master’s goods.
Has already possessed his wife. Pauli (ed. Bolte) No. 613.

content:
Faithful servant entrusted with care and education of crown
prince.

King demands work, sport or entertainment from winter
guests.
child:
Christian king makes baptism a condition for hospitality
during the winter.

content: Teacher dies of pride over success of pupil.
Poor person makes great effort to entertain guests.
child:
Poor host and his wife kill themselves because they are
unable to entertain expected guests.

Wife scolds husband‘s hospitality, as he really has nothing
to give.

Poor peasant closes the eyes in order not to see guest eat:
later suicide.

content: English romance: Malory passim; Icelandic: Boberg.
child: Host treats guest with food and everything possible.

content: Refusal to believe that a friend has spoken ill of one.
child: Refusal to believe that a friend will harm one.

Alexander drinks cup said to have been poisoned by his
friend. Spanish Exempla: Keller.

content: Teacher threatens to curse pupils if they disobey.
Host surrenders his wife to his guest.

The guest unwittingly
falls in love with the wife. The host, on being informed, out of pure
generosity repudiates the wife and has her marry the guest. (Often joined with
†P315.) Chauvin V 136 No. 64; also references to †P315; Spanish Exempla:
Keller.
child: Guest begets son with his host’s daughter.

content:
*Types 516; *BP I 46; **Rösch FFC LXXVII 95f.; **Hdwb. d.
Märchens I 389 (and cross references there given); Icelandic: *Boberg; Spanish
Exempla: Keller; Jewish: *Neuman; India: Thompson-Balys; Korean: Zong in-Sob
154ff. No. 68.
child: Faithful servant dies for his master.

Puts on his master‘s clothes so as to be slain in his place. (Cf. †P316.) Alphabet
No. 327; Japanese: Ikeda.

Faithful servant kills his master‘s murderer and is killed
in turn.

Faithful servant wants to follow on dangerous quest, where
he alone is killed.
Hero’s charioteer faithful to master till death.

Faithful servant remains at home and fights for exiled
hero.
Faithful servant sacrifices sons to save life of king.

Sons resuscitated and servant enriched. Penzer IV 177f.,
VI 272f.; India: Thompson-Balys.

Faithful nurse tries to save tyrant’s daughter by exposing
her own in her place.
Abandoned maiden helped by her faithful nurse.
Faithful servant dies avenging master‘s death.
Captain will not betray king’s secret.

He refuses to betray where recruits are being raised.
Spanish: Childers.
Faithful servant undergoes torture for sake of his master.
Crow lets itself be caught so as to save king of crows.
